title-group.article-title: Reputation, Certification, Warranties, and Information as Remedies for Seller‐Buyer Information Asymmetries: Lessons from the Online Comic Book Market*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Signaling strategies that sellers of higher‐quality products or securities employ to differentiate their products include (1) development of a reputation for quality, (2) third‐party certification, (3) warranties, and (4) information disclosure. These signaling strategies are compared using data from the online auction market for classic comic books. This market’s advantages include that (1) the information asymmetry is substantial, (2) good measures of reputation are available, and (3) all four signals are common. We explore which signals are strongest and why, which are substitutes or complements, and how choice among the other three strategies depends on the reputation of the seller.

fn.p: The authors are grateful to James Philpot, Scott Linn, Bob Lipe, and participants in the University of Oklahoma finance workshop for helpful comments. Comments and suggestions by an anonymous referee were especially helpful. Contact the corresponding author, Louis Ederington, atlederington@ou.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This paper empirically compares four signaling strategies that sellers of high‐quality goods, services, or securities often employ in an attempt to differentiate their products from those of lower quality. Since the publication of Akerlof’s (1970) seminal lemons paper, economists have identified and analyzed a number of strategies that sellers of high‐quality goods or services or issuers of high‐quality securities might utilize to distinguish their products from those of lower quality. One analyzed by Klein and Leffler (1981), Shapiro (1982,1983), and Diamond (1989), among others, is to invest resources in developing a reputation for high‐quality products. A second possible strategy (Grossman1981; Wiener1985; Gal‐Or1989) is to offer a warranty or “money‐back” guarantee. Third, high‐quality sellers or issuers sometimes seek certification by a respected third party (Carter and Manaster1990; Anderson, Daly, and Johnson1999), such as, auditors, bond rating agencies (Moody's and Standard and Poors), securities underwriters, testing organizations, (e.g., Underwriters Laboratory or the International Standards Organization [ISO]), and professional licensing bodies. Fourth, the seller or issuer may provide information to the prospective purchaser, for example, advertising, financial statements, specifications, and test results. Some signals, such as audited financial statements, combine two or more strategies.

While each of these strategies has received considerable theoretical attention, empirical studies have been more limited. Moreover, to our knowledge, no one has conducted a comparison of the different strategies either theoretically or empirically. For instance, when a seller is analyzing the choice of whether or not to offer a warranty, the only allowed alternative is generally to do nothing—not to seek certification or provide information. Likewise, to our knowledge, no one has asked how the decision to offer a warranty or seek certification depends on the seller’s reputation. Yet obviously the availability of alternatives could be important. Suppose that high‐quality sellers can choose between signaling strategies A and B, which are equally costly to them. Suppose that all low‐quality sellers find signal A prohibitively costly to mimic and most, but not all, find B too costly to mimic. Although B might lead to a partial separating equilibrium in the absence of A, in the presence of A, rational buyers should reason that a truly high‐quality seller would choose A so that those who choose B are likely of lower quality. Consequently, we would expect the most effective signaling strategy to eviscerate the less effective.

In this paper we compare these four information asymmetry remedies using data from eBay’s comic book auction market. For several reasons, the online market for classic comic books provides an almost ideal experiment for this comparison. First, the information asymmetry is serious and important. Time and kids have not always been kind to comic books, so quality differs greatly and the quality/price of comic books graded “good” is roughly 10% of the price of a “near‐mint” comic book. Between more extreme grades, the price differentials are even greater, and our data indicate that these traditional guidelines understate current price differentials. Obviously, since the online buyer cannot handle and examine the book, the information asymmetry is considerable. Second, in this market, there are a large number of sellers employing a variety of informational strategies. For instance, in our data set there are 1,398 unique sellers, and each of the four signaling strategies—reputation building, third‐party certification, warranties, and information disclosure—is employed by a substantial number. Third, reliable data are readily available. For instance, empirical research on reputation as a remedy for the seller‐buyer information asymmetry has been hampered by the lack of good measures for reputation. Researchers have had to rely on such proxies as advertising expenditures (Sappington and Wernerfelt1985), market share (Megginson and Weiss1991), and position in tombstone ads (Carter and Manaster1990). However, eBay invites all buyers and sellers in its auctions to rate their satisfaction with the other party and then posts the results. While imperfect, these feedback ratings, which are often cited as a major factor in eBay’s success, provide a much better measure of reputation than those available heretofore. Our findings include the following.

Certification.—Third‐party certification of a comic’s quality by Comic Guaranty LLC sends the strongest signal. On average, certified copies sell for roughly 50% more than uncertified comics of the same claimed quality, and the percentage differential is higher at the higher grades. Certified books command a higher differential over uncertified if the seller’s reputation is ill defined or poor, but certification results in a higher price regardless of the seller’s reputation. The differential is also greater if it appears that the seller should have sought certification if the comic’s condition was truly as good as claimed. It appears that part of the price differential between certified and uncertified comics is due to risk reduction in that a price differential exists even when there is no reason to expect uncertified books to be of lower quality.

Reputation.—Two aspects of reputation affect the price: (1) how much is known about the seller and (2) whether what is known is good or bad. Books from a seller with a positive reputation sell for more than books from a seller with a negative reputation. Also, books from sellers with established reputations tend to sell for more than those from sellers with nonexistent or fledgling reputations. However, the price differentials between sellers with well‐established positive reputations and those with negative or undeveloped reputations are less than those between certified and uncertified comic books. Evidence supports the view that bidders are Bayesians updating their subjective probability that the seller is dishonest or unreliable as feedback from previous buyers accumulates, but they appear to place little weight on their priors relative to the sample information even when the latter appears of dubious value.

Warranties.—Although we find that warranties in the form of money‐back guarantees tend to be offered by reputable dealers on higher‐value comics, there is no evidence that books with warranties sell for more than those without. Apparently, buyers either view these warranties as too costly to enforce or reason that sellers of truly high‐quality comics should seek certification and so discount warranties. Despite that fact that there is no evidence that warranties affect the price, there is evidence that a minority of sellers view them as a possible substitute for certification.

Information disclosure.— Our evidence indicates that voluntary disclosure in the form of scans leads to a partial but relatively ineffective separation of high‐ and low‐quality comic books. Specifically, failure to provide a scan reduces the price by a significant, but fairly modest, 12%–17%. The fact that scans are provided for over 96.5% of the comics in our data set indicates that most sellers of lower‐quality books find it relatively easy to mimic this strategy of the higher‐quality sellers.

Overall, our results indicate that information asymmetry and signaling are important. The prices realized by sellers who send credible signals of high quality, certification in particular, are substantially higher than the prices realized by sellers who do not. Our evidence also indicates that alternatives are important: that strategies for ameliorating an information asymmetry should not be considered in isolation because the most effective strategies further weaken the less effective. Risk reduction is also important. Signals that leave unchanged the expected value of bidders’ perceptions of the likely quality of the comic but reduce uncertainty about the comic’s quality result in higher prices.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. InSection II, we describe the online comic book market and briefly review existing research on other online auction markets. InSection III, we describe our data set and our measures of the four signaling strategies: reputation, certification, warranties, and information disclosure. InSection IV, we test how the prices of comic books in this auction market depend on signals sent by the seller. InSection V, we examine reputation more closely, modeling it in a Bayesian framework in which buyers update their priors that the seller is honest and reliable as evidence accumulates. InSection VI, we explore what determines the seller’s choice of signaling strategies. InSection VIIwe return to the certification signal asking whether reaction to the signal is conditional on the apparent net benefit of certification to the seller.Section VIIIsummarizes our findings for each signaling strategy and concludes the paper.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Collectible Comic Books and eBay Auctions

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Market for Collectible Comic Books
sec.p: This paper examines the online auction market for collectible comic books from what is generally referred to as comics’ “Silver Age,” the period from 1956 to 1969, when superheroes, such as Spiderman, ruled supreme. This is the most active collectible comics market. For instance, on August 16, 2002, eBay had 16,558 auctions underway in Silver Age comics versus 5,087 for comics published before 1956 and 10,181 for comics published from 1970 to 1980. Obviously, time and kids have taken their toll on comics from this era, so quality varies widely and is a major determinant of a comic's price. The grading scheme that has evolved in the marketplace recognizes 25 different grades based on such characteristics as tears, creases, whiteness of the paper, gloss of the cover colors, and condition of the spine. Major grades are poor, fair, good, very good, fine, very fine, near‐mint, and mint. Such intermediate grades as fine+, fine−, and fine/very fine round out the 25 grades. Traditionally, dealers price good and fine comic books at roughly 10% and 25%, respectively, of the price of a near‐mint book.

In an Internet comic book auction (or mail‐order sale) the information asymmetry between the seller and buyer is obviously much greater than in a dealer’s shop or at a comic book show since the buyer cannot personally inspect the book. Hence, seller and buyer must rely on some combination of reputation, warranties, scanned images, and third‐party certification to resolve the quality uncertainty and avoid a lemons problem.

Arrangements in which the seller hires a trusted third party to certify the quality of its product or service are common in many markets. They are ubiquitous in financial markets in which auditors, bond‐rating agencies (such as Moody's and Standard and Poors), and investment banks and underwriters all fill this role. Examples in product markets include Underwriters Laboratory and the ISO.1While certification agents have long been part of the collectible stamp and coin markets, there was no such agent in the comic book market until 1999 when Comics Guaranty LLC (CGC) entered the market.2For a fee, which ranges from $20 to $55 for the majority of comics in our data set, CGC will grade and certify a comic. To maintain the integrity of its certification, CGC encapsulates the certified comic in a plastic casing. If the casing is opened, the certification is invalidated. Obviously, this limitation imposes an additional cost on the collector since she cannot open or read the comic without destroying its certification.

fn.p: In a broader sense such testing agencies as Consumers Union could be viewed as certification agencies, but we restrict the term to cases in which the cost is borne by the seller.
A second comic book grading agency entered the market in 2003. To date there have been few auctions of books graded by this competitor.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: eBay Auctions
sec.p: The growth of the Internet, and eBay in particular, has transformed the markets for collectibles including classic comic books. A spot check of eBay auctions of March 3, 2002, found 14,092 auctions in progress of Silver Age (1956–69) comic books. In comparison, on the same day, there were 2,674 such auctions in progress on Amazon and 599 on Yahoo. In setting up an eBay auction, the seller sets four parameters: (1) the starting time and length of the auction (three, five, seven, or 10 days), (2) the minimum acceptable bid, (3) the acceptable means of payment (money order, credit card, personal check), and (4) shipping charges if any. The seller can also decide to include scans of the comic book, to offer a money‐back guarantee, and/or to set a secret reserve price (for a fee).

eBay’s auctions are variations of Vickrey’s second‐price sealed‐bid auction in that the winner pays the second‐highest bid plus a set increment. Bidders choose a reservation price, and the eBay computer then enters the minimum bid (below this reservation price) that will lead the bidding. For example, suppose that a seller posts an item with a minimum acceptable bid of $100. Suppose that the first bidder, A, enters a reservation price of $110. The eBay computer posts A as the highest bidder at $100. If bidder B enters the bidding with a reservation price of $125, she becomes the high bidder at $112.50—A’s reservation price plus the preset $2.50 increment. If B had instead set a maximum bid of $105, A would have remained the high bidder at $107.50—B’s limit plus $2.50. Hence the winner pays the reservation price of the second‐highest bidder plus a small increment. Given this pricing scheme, minimum bids and reserve prices essentially introduce an additional bidder into the process.

eBay auctions have been the subject of considerable research in recent years (for an excellent review, see Bajari and Hortaçsu [forthcoming]). Attention has focused on questions of auction design (such as the ascending auction second‐price structure, minimum bids, secret reserve prices, and auction length). Researchers have also explored the late bidding strategy (most bids are submitted in the final minutes) (e.g., Roth and Ockenfels2002) and whether the auctions exhibit a winner’s curse (Bajari and Hortaçsu2003).

Most relevant for the present paper are those papers examining the role played by eBay’s feedback mechanism. As noted above, lack of a good measure of reputation has hampered past efforts to empirically test its efficacy as a signal of quality. eBay’s feedback ratings provide such a measure. After each auction, eBay invites the buyer and seller to express their satisfaction with the other’s performance by assigning a positive, neutral, or negative rating to the transaction. According to Resnick and Zeckhauser (2002), roughly 52% of buyers and 61% of sellers provide such feedback. The parties can also make comments. The number of net positive (positive minus negative) responses is displayed on the main page; by clicking on the seller’s rating, prospective buyers can see detailed statistics and individual comments.3As documented by Resnick and Zeckhauser, the feedbacks tend to be overwhelmingly positive—about 99% for sellers and 98% for buyers.

A number of papers have examined how these feedback ratings affect the price, including McDonald and Slawson (2002) (Barbie dolls), Houser and Wooders (forthcoming) (microprocessors), Lucking‐Reiley et al. (2000) (coins), Melnik and Alm (2002) (coins), Jin and Kato (2002) (baseball cards), Bajari and Hortaçsu (2003) (coins), and Resnick et al. (2003) (vintage postcards).4While results vary, most find that sellers with better reputations receive somewhat higher prices. However, as several commentators have noted, a surprising aspect of these studies is not so much that reputation matters but that, in light of the serious information asymmetry, it does not matter more. For instance, Houser and Wooders estimate that a 10% increase in the number of positive responses raises the sale price only 0.17%, whereas a 10% increase in negative responses lowers the price −0.24%. Lucking‐Reiley et al. estimate that a 10% increase in positive (negative) responses raises (lowers) the price 0.3% (−1.1%). In a controlled experiment, Resnick et al. sold matched pairs of collectible postcards on eBay through (1) an established seller with over 2,000 positive feedbacks and only one negative one, (2) new sellers with a few (< 17) positive and no negative feedbacks, and (3) new sellers with a sizable proportion of negative feedbacks. The established seller realized an 8.1% average premium over the newcomers, but there was no significant difference between the newcomers with only positive and those with some negative feedbacks.

Several explanations have been offered for the relatively modest impact of feedback ratings on prices. Noting that the vast majority of feedbacks are positive, Bajari and Hortaçsu (forthcoming) argue that the rating mechanism provides a strong incentive to sellers to provide good service, leading to an equilibrium in which almost all have very good reputations. Of course an alternative possibility is that the buyers do not fully trust the ratings. For instance, McDonald and Slawson (2002) and Resnick and Zeckhauser (2002), among others, argue that buyers may be reluctant to give a seller a negative rating for fear of retaliation.5Also, at the time of these studies and ours, the ratings did not distinguish between transactions in which the party was a seller and those in which it was a buyer.

To our knowledge, third‐party certification in an electronic auction context has been explored only by Jin and Kato (2002), and no one has explored the impact of warranties and information disclosure. Jin and Kato's findings for eBay auctions of baseball trading cards include the following: professionally graded cards sell for considerably more than nongraded cards with the same claimed high grade, sellers of self‐graded cards exaggerate their quality, the reputation of the seller has little impact on the price received, and unsubstantiated claims of very high quality on cards that are not professionally graded result in higher prices even though there is a higher likelihood that either no card or a counterfeit card will be delivered by sellers making such claims and no difference in card quality, on average, from those claiming more moderate quality levels.

The availability of other strategies may explain why previous studies find that reputation’s impact is surprisingly small. For instance, if high‐quality goods are normally certified, buyers would be rational to question why the seller of an uncertified good did not seek certification even if her reputation is stellar. Note that while reputation is a long‐run strategy, the others are short‐run. At the time a seller lists an item for sale on eBay, she cannot change her reputation but can decide to seek certification, offer a warranty, and/or provide detailed information.

fn.p: In 2003 eBay also began reporting the percentage of positive feedbacks on the main page.
For a more extensive list and good summary, see Resnick et al. (2003).

An examination of the comments accompanying negative ratings supports this view. A buyer or seller who receives a negative rating often responds that it was a meritless retaliatory response to a negative rating that they had given the other party for good cause.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Data, Signaling Measures, and Estimation Procedures

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Data
sec.p:
For this study we collected data on eBay auctions ending between January 12, 2001, and June 23, 2001, of the 30 Silver Age comic books listed intable 1—a total of 4,012 auctions.6Because the extent and quality of any restoration work can differ tremendously and are hard to quantify, we dropped from the data set 201 comics that were identified as having been restored. We also dropped 147 sold through eBay’s “buy‐it‐now” option, leaving a sample of 3,664 observations. Characteristics of the 30 comic books as well as the entire sample are reported intable 1. The mean price is $357, but with a standard deviation of $1,439, there is great variation. The median grade is fine−, and 61.2% of the auctions result in a sale. Table 1

fn.p: The 30 comic books were chosen by first checking eBay in early January for comics that were (1) heavily traded and (2) fairly expensive, so certification was a reasonable option. We did not collect data on an auction (1) if the data were incomplete (such as no grade assigned) or (2) if it was obvious from the scan that the assigned grade was totally unrealistic. The latter represent less than 2% of the total auctions.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: The Price Measure and Estimation Procedure
sec.p: Our first objective is to test how the price of a classic comic in an online auction depends on actions taken by the seller to resolve the information asymmetry controlling for the other factors that affect the price. This is complicated by the fact that some auctions do not result in a sale either because no one was willing to bid above the minimum bid (which is observed) or because the highest bid was below a secret reserve price. Econometric studies of eBay auctions follow roughly identical procedures for dealing with the no‐sale problem. The dependent variable is generally measured as the price (or its log) if the auction results in a sale and as the highest bid if there is no sale because the highest bid was below an unobserved secret reserve price. A Tobit procedure is then generally employed to control for the fact that in some auctions, no bids are received because no one is willing to bid above the (observed) minimum bid. Using the high bid when there is no sale because of a secret reserve price may introduce a slight bias. As described above, in a successful sale, the winner pays a price equal to the reservation price of thesecond‐highest bidder plus the minimum increment. When there is no sale because of a secret reserve, the recorded price is the reservation price of the highest bidder, not the second‐highest (which is unobservable), so it may be biased upward.7Since to exclude these observations would introduce a sample selection bias, we follow the standard approach; that is, our dependent variable, ln(PRICE), is the log of the price if the item is sold and the highest bid if it is not. However, we include a zero‐one dummy to designate the presence of a secret reserve to account for any possible bias.

fn.p: Sellers may use a secret reserve price to judge the demand for the item and then contact the highest bidder and try to negotiate a higher price.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Signaling Variables
sec.p: We are mainly interested in how the price received in an auction depends on actions taken by the seller to ameliorate the information asymmetry regarding the comic’s condition testing four possible signaling strategies: reputation, certification, warranties, and information disclosures.

Reputation.—As reviewed above, reputation, as measured by eBay’s feedback ratings, is a common variable in previous studies. While a few use eBay’s net measure, the more common procedure is to include the number (usually in log form) of positive and negative (or nonpositive) responses as separate variables. This allows the impact of an additional negative feedback to differ from the impact of an additional positive response.

Most comics in our sample are offered by sellers with very positive and well‐established reputations. The mean and median numbers of feedbacks from previous customers are 365 and 181 in our sample. Nonetheless, there are 318 auctions in our sample by sellers with no feedback ratings and others with just a few. The mean of NEGPCT is only 0.502%, and 59.4% of our sellers have no negative feedbacks.

Certification.—To identify those comics with certified grades, we define CERT = 1 if the comic has been certified by CGC and zero otherwise. As explored below, certification fees range from $20 for turnaround time in 25–30 business days for comics with an estimated value of $250 or less to $95 for one‐day service on books with an estimated value above $5,000. In our sample, 27.9% of the comics are certified. As one would expect given the cost structure, certification is more common for more valuable comics. For instance, among comics rated very fine or higher, 53% are certified whereas only 4% of those rated good or lower are certified.

Warranties.—The variable WARRANTY = 1 if the seller promises to refund the purchase price in full if the buyer is dissatisfied and zero otherwise.10A positive coefficient is predicted. Overall, 14.2% of the comics in our sample carry such a warranty. In virtually all cases, the buyer would still be out the cost of returning the comic to the seller. An issue with warranties in such markets as consumer durables is the cost of enforcement, particularly since sellers often include a long list of circumstances in which the warranty is void. While the money‐back guarantees in the comic book market do not normally include such qualifications, the buyer may well wonder what her recourse is if the seller does not honor the warranty. She may discount the warranty’s value for this reason.

Information disclosure.—It is common for sellers of goods, services, and securities to provide the prospective buyer with information in the form of advertising, specifications, or financial statements. In the online comic book market this information disclosure takes the form of a claimed grade (which all the comics in our sample have) and scanned images (which 96.5% include). The scans almost always show the front cover and sometimes the back cover and inside details. We define the variable NOSCAN = 1 if the seller fails to provide a scan and zero otherwise. A negative coefficient is expected. A problem with scans is that while they give the buyer an indication of the book’s condition, they are usually not detailed enough to provide a complete picture. In particular, they usually fail to reveal the presence of restorative work.

fn.p: The 1.0 is included in the denominator of NEGPCT to avoid a zero denominator in the case of new sellers. Buyers may also provide a “neutral” feedback, though that is quite rare. We treat these as providing no information and ignore them.

Payment by a credit card may provide an implicit warranty since a dissatisfied buyer may be able to stop payment. However, buyers may be reluctant to provide their credit card number online—particularly if the site is not secure. Also, small sellers may be reluctant to accept credit card payments because of either the cost involved or the fear that buyers will stop payment. Because of this ambiguity, we decided not to include a dummy variable for sellers accepting credit card payments in our main regressions. However, we have run estimations with such a variable. It is insignificant and has little impact on the other parameter estimates.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Control Variables
sec.p:
We also include a number of control variables. One is the comic’s claimed grade. There are 23 separate grades in our data set ranging from poor to near‐mint/mint. Since the relation between price and grade may not be linear, we assign zero/one dummy variables, GRADE j , for all gradesjexcept poor (the left‐out category). Obviously, we expect positive coefficients and further expect them to increase monotonically with the grade. The distribution of the grades is shown infigure 1, where we report certified and noncertified comics separately. Several points stand out from this graph. First, there is a wide grade dispersion, though most are concentrated in the middle grades. Second, grades are higher on certified books. Third, there is a tendency for noncertified books to be bunched in the more basic categories, such as good, very good, and fine, rather than in the finer categorizations such as good+, very good−, or good/very good, which may indicate that nonprofessional graders have difficulty making finer quality distinctions. Fig. 1.—
Grade distribution for certified and noncertified comic books

As noted above, our data set encompasses 30 different comic issues. As reported intable 1, because of collector interest and scarcity, their mean prices differ widely. Accordingly, we use 29 different zero‐one dummy variables, BOOK i , to identify the different issues, withX‐Men16 as the left‐out issue. Issues that tend to have higher or lower values thanX‐Men16 should have positive and negative coefficients, respectively, but we do not hypothesize which these should be.

As noted above, many previous studies of online markets have explored how auction design affects price. While that is not our focus here, we control for these possible price determinants. Sellers can decide on three‐, five‐, seven‐, or 10‐day auctions. While bidding is normally highly concentrated in the last few hours, there is some evidence (Lucking‐Reiley et al.2000; Houser and Wooders,forthcoming) that longer auctions attract more bidders, resulting in a higher price. Accordingly, we define zero‐one dummies, D5, D7, and D10, for five‐, seven‐, and 10‐day auctions, respectively. Finally, we include a dummy RESERVE to designate those auctions in which the seller sets a secret reserve price: 29.8% of our sample. Lucking‐Reiley et al. find significant positive coefficients for this variable. As explained above, this does not necessarily mean that including a reserve raises the price since when an item does not sell because of a high reserve, the dependent variable is the highest bid, not the second‐highest.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Procedures
sec.p:
In summary, the estimated equation is
In 758 or 20.7% of our 3,664 observations, no bids were received, so the data are left truncated at the minimum bid set by the seller. To obtain consistent parameter estimates in light of this truncation, we utilize both a Tobit estimation procedure and Heckman’s least‐squares procedure. For the former we use the minimum bid as the left‐truncation level. For the Heckman estimation, we first estimate the likelihood of receiving bids as a function of the minimum bid and the comic's characteristics described above (results available on request) and then form the inverse Mills ratio, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $n( p> mb) / N( p> mb) $ \end{document} , wheren() andN() are the normal density and distribution functions, respectively;pis the price or value of the comic; andmbis the minimum bid. This variable, IMills i , is then included as an additional variable in an ordinary least squares regression over the 2,906 observations in which bids were received.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Basic Results
sec.p:
Results of the estimation ofequation (1)are reported intable 2.11As shown there, our model explains almost 95% of the variation in the price across the various auctions. All signaling variable coefficients have the predicted signs, and most are significant at the .01 level. The two estimation procedures, Tobit and Heckman, yield quite similar coefficient estimates. Note.—The log of the sale price (or highest bid) for classic comics is regressed on (1) a dummy for third‐party certification (CERT), negative feedback ratings of the seller as a percentage of total feedbacks (NEGPCT), the reciprocal of the square root of the number of feedbacks for the seller (STDDEV), a dummy for comics with money‐back guarantees (WARRANTY), a dummy for failure to provide a scan (NOSCAN), dummies for the grade assigned to the comic (above poor) (GRADE j ), dummies for the different books as listed intable 1(BOOK1) (these coefficients are not reported below but are available on request), dummies for auction length in days (D5, D7, and D10) if greater than three days, and a dummy for the presence of a secret reserve price (RESERVE). The sample is left truncated at the minimum bid. The estimation is based on 3,664 eBay auctions of Silver Age comic book auctions on eBay over the period January 12, 2001–June 23, 2001.

Certification.—Clearly, certified comics sell for considerably more than otherwise identical noncertified comics. The coefficient of the CERT variable is .458 in the Tobit estimation and .463 in the Heckman estimation. In nonlog terms, these coefficients imply that comic books with grades certified by CGC tend to sell for about 58%–59% more than similarly graded noncertified comics.12Clearly third‐party certification provides a signal that buyers take very seriously.

Reputation.—The coefficient of STDDEV is negative and significantly different from zero at the .01 level in both estimations, indicating that how much buyers know about the seller matters, that is, that buyers penalize sellers with few feedbacks from previous customers. The coefficient of NEGPCT is also negative as hypothesized and significant at the .01 level, indicating that buyers penalize sellers with a high proportion of negative feedbacks. In other words, both the mean and standard deviation of the sample proportion of negative feedbacks affect the price. According to our Tobit (Heckman) regression estimates, the price received by a seller with 100 positive feedbacks and no negative feedbacks tends to be about 8.1% (11.0%) higher than that received by a seller of the same book with no feedback ratings. In 59.4% of our auctions, the percentage of negative feedbacks is zero, and in 5.5%, it exceeds 2.5%. Our Tobit estimates imply that the prices obtained by sellers with 2.5% negative ratings are about 2.3% lower than those obtained by sellers with no negative ratings. According to the Heckman estimates, the price difference is about 2.7%.

While significant, the impact of reputation on the price is considerably less than that of certification. As noted above, on average, certified books command prices more that 58% higher than similar noncertified books. On the basis of the estimated coefficients of NEGPCT and STDDEV, the percentage difference in the price received by the seller with the best reputation among our 3,664 and the seller with the worst reputation is about 45%. A one‐standard‐deviation change in NEGPCT translates into a 1.6% change in the price according to the Tobit estimates and 1.8% according to the Heckman estimates. A one‐standard‐deviation change in STDDEV translates into a 2.5% (3.4%) change in the price according to the Tobit (Heckman) estimates. By comparison, the corresponding figures are 22.8% (Tobit) and 23.0% (Heckman) for CERT.

Warranties.—The variable WARRANTY, which designates comics with a money‐back guarantee, is the only insignificant signaling variable. While positive as predicted, the estimated price increment is less than 2.5% and insignificant. A possible explanation is that buyers may view the costs of enforcing the warranty as prohibitive since a dissatisfied customer must normally pay the return postage and may have difficulty forcing the seller to honor the guarantee. Also, the effectiveness of warranties may be undermined by the presence of more effective signals, such as certification.

Information disclosures.—Failure to provide a scan (which occurs in only 3.5% of our sample) lowers the price an average of 11.3% according to our Tobit estimates and 13.7% according to our Heckman estimates. While these are meaningful price differences, we had expected that failure to provide a scan would lower the price even more. Possible reasons are explored inSection Vbelow.

Control variables.—The considerable impact of the auctioned comic’s claimed condition is readily apparent from our coefficient estimates for GRADE j . As noted above, a traditional rule of thumb in the industry is that comic books graded good and fine sell for roughly 10% and 25%, respectively, of the price of the same book in near‐mint condition. Our estimates indicate that actual price differentials are almost double these rules of thumb. Specifically, our Tobit coefficients indicate that comics graded good sell for about 5.7% of the near‐mint price and comics graded fine sell for about 13.9% of the near‐mint price. The Heckman coefficients imply 5.7% and 13.8%, respectively. With the single exception of an inversion in the implied prices of the good/very good and very good grades in the Heckman estimation, prices increase monotonically with the claimed grade.

There is also evidence that running the auction longer results in a higher price. Since three‐day auctions are the left‐out group, our estimates imply that auctioning a book for five days instead of three raises the price 9%–12% and that extending the auction to 10 days results in a slightly higher price. The dummy for the presence of a secret reserve price is small, negative, and significant in the Tobit estimation but positive, small, and insignificant in the Heckman estimation.13

Summary.— In summary, of the four possible strategies that sellers of high‐quality comic books might undertake to reduce the information asymmetry, we find that three (seeking third‐party certification, developing a positive reputation, and disclosing information) raise the price. There is no evidence that offering a money‐back guarantee raises the price. Of the three effective strategies, obtaining third‐party certification has the greatest impact—raising the price more than 50% relative to uncertified comics of the same claimed quality.

fn.p: Coefficients of the 29 dummy variables, BOOK i , for the individual comic issues are not reported.

As noted above, a positive coefficient does not necessarily mean that adding a secret reserve tends to raise the price received since the sample dependent variable is based on the highest bid when the item fails to sell because of a high reserve price.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Signal Interactions and Conditionality
sec.p: Attention is now turned to questions of how the impact of a particular signal on the price depends on what other information the bidders have and what other signals the seller sends.

Results forequation (2b)are reported intable 3. As hypothesized, the percentage impact of certification on the price is a positive function of the claimed grade. The implication is that certification adds nothing to the price of a comic rated poor—as we hypothesized it should not. For comics rated good, our results indicate that certification raises the price about 24.2%. The implied price differential is 37.0% for comics rated very good, 52.3% for those rated fine, 73.1% for those rated very fine, and 127.2% for those rated near‐mint. Note.—The log of the sale price or highest bid for a comic is regressed on signaling variables for reputation, certification, warranties, and information disclosure; control variables for the comic’s type and grade; and the auction characteristics allowing for interactions between the signaling variables. The estimated equations, (2) and(3), are shown in the text. The equations are estimated on the basis of 2,906 eBay auctions of Silver Age comic books over the period January 12, 2001–June 23, 2001, using the Heckman procedure to account for the fact that the data are left‐truncated at the minimum bid.

Reputation and certification.—Next, we explore whether other signals matter more if the book is not certified, starting with reputation. We hypothesize that reputation matters more for uncertified books than for certified books or, alternatively, that certification is more important if the seller does not have an established positive reputation. Certifying agencies, such as bond‐rating agencies and testing laboratories, are effectively selling their reputation to their customers. Their livelihood depends on maintaining a trusted reputation that exceeds that of their customers. Since on a certified comic book the seller has effectively substituted the reputation of the certifying agency for its own reputation, we hypothesize that the seller’s reputation will matter less for certified comics. Indeed, if the comic book’s condition were the only aspect of the trade with an information asymmetry, reputation should not matter at all for certified comics. However, buyers may well be concerned about other aspects of the trade. An unscrupulous seller might fail to deliver or substitute a different comic. For instance, Jin and Kato (2002) report that in 11 of 100 trials, the seller either failed to deliver or substituted a counterfeit baseball card.

fn.p: When eqq.(2a)and(2b)are estimated with WARRANTY, it remains insignificant as ineq. (1), and the other coefficients are little changed from those reported here.

Apparently multicollinearity between the many variables involving certification ineq. (3)pushes up the standard errors, making testing difficult. If the certification‐scan interaction variable is dropped fromeq. (3), the standard error of λ2falls considerably, though not quite enough to make λ2significant at the .01 level.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Our results for the four signaling strategies may be summarized as follows.

Third‐party certification.—Of the four signaling strategies, obtaining third‐party certification has the greatest impact on the price. According to our estimates, certification by the CGC raises the price over 50% on average, and the impact is roughly proportional to the comic’s quality rising from 0% for poor comics to over 100% for comics in near‐mint condition.

Reputation.—We find that both how much buyers know about the seller and whether what they know is good or bad affect the price. In other words, both the mean and variance of the proportion of negative feedbacks matter. The prices received by sellers rise as both the proportion of negative feedbacks falls and the number of feedbacks from previous buyers rises. As expected, we find that reputation is less important if the comic being offered for sale is certified.

Information disclosure.—Failure to provide a scanned image of the comic book lowers the realized price roughly 11%–14%. Since scans are provided in 96.5% of the auctions, it appears unlikely that scans separate out all the lower‐quality sellers.

Warranties.—We find no evidence that offering a warranty in the form of a money‐back guarantee significantly affects the price. Apparently, prospective buyers view the costs of enforcing such warranties as prohibitive and/or they reason that sellers of truly high‐quality comics have better signaling strategies available.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Reputation in a Bayesian Framework16
sec.p: We now examine more closely how the seller’s reputation affects the price received. In equations(1)and (2), we used two measures of reputation: (1) the sample proportion of negative feedbacks, NEGPCT i , and (2) a proxy for the standard deviation of the proportion of negative feedbacks, STDDEV i . We found support for our hypotheses that price received increases as the proportion of negative feedbacks declines and as uncertainty about the proportion declines.

This focus on the sample statistics ignores the fact that buyers may have strong priors about the likelihood of bad service. Moreover, additional feedbacks may affect the expected probability of a negative experience as well as the variance of that probability even if the proportion of negative feedbacks is unchanged. Resnick and Zeckhauser (2002) report that the likelihood of a bad experience with a particular seller is strongly related to the number of feedbacks. Specifically, the likelihood of a bad experience (as indicated by a subsequent negative or neutral feedback on the transaction) is 2.83% for sellers with fewer than 10 prior feedbacks versus 0.79% for sellers with 200–999 prior feedbacks. Consequently, it is possible that if a seller has no prior feedbacks, buyers assign a fairly high prior probability to the likelihood of an unsatisfactory experience, such as bad service, deception, or fraud and that this high subjective probability is gradually reduced as evidence accumulates if the proportion of actual bad experiences is in the normal range.

As shown by their estimated standard errors intable 4, the parametersaandbare not measured with much precision. Nonetheless, the evidence indicates (1) that the prior probability of a negative experience that buyers assign to a seller with no prior history is fairly high and (2) that this prior is weakly held so that it is adjusted sharply as previous buyers report their experiences. The estimated prior probability for a negative experience with a seller with no past history is 12.3%. If the seller has one positive feedback, the implied posterior probability falls to 3.0%; if the seller has two positive feedbacks, the implied posterior is 1.7%; and if five, 0.8%.

How reliable and realistic are these estimates? The estimate of 12.3% for the prior probability of a negative experience with a seller with no prior history is surprisingly large. The estimated standard error of this estimate is also high, but the null that the prior is 3% or less is rejected at the .05 level. So it seems clear that the buyer attaches a fairly high prior to the likelihood that a seller with no record will be dishonest or unreliable. As noted above, Resnick and Zeckhauser (2002) report that for sellers with fewer than 10 prior feedbacks, the proportion of negative feedbacks on the next sale is 2.83%. Unfortunately, they do not report figures separately for sellers with no prior feedbacks. If we calculate the implied negative experience posterior probabilities for sellers with zero to nine prior feedbacks and weight them equally, the average is 2.21%, or reasonably close to the Resnick‐Zeckhauser percentage. However, sellers with zero prior feedbacks are much more plentiful than those with two to nine in our sample; and if we weight the posterior probabilities by their relative frequency in our sample, the average is 8.1%, or much higher than the Resnick‐Zeckhauser percentage. Our figures suggest, therefore, that buyers overestimate the likelihood of a bad experience with a seller with no prior record.

The estimate of −.914 for β1is in line with what one would expect for rational value‐maximizing buyers. If the probability of a bad experience isx% and if in these cases the buyer receives nothing and so loses the amount paid, then rational buyers should reduce the price they are willing to payx% to compensate implying a coefficient of −1. In many cases the defrauded buyer receives something (just a lower‐quality comic than expected), implying an absolute coefficient less than one; but the buyer is also out her time, implying an absolute coefficient greater than one. Consequently, the coefficient of −.914 is in line with our expectations and implies that the buyers are valuing reputation rationally.

fn.p: The authors wish to thank the referee for suggesting that we model reputation in a Bayesian framework.
Specifically,

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: The Seller’s Strategy Choice
sec.p: Attention is now turned to the seller’s signaling strategy decision. While reputation is a long‐run strategy, third‐party certification, information disclosure, and warranties are short‐run strategies. In other words, in a particular auction, there is little or nothing the seller can do to improve her reputation in time to help sell that comic book, but she can choose among the third‐party certification, information disclosure, and warranty strategies. Consequently, in this section we view the seller’s reputation as exogenous and examine her choices among the three other strategies.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Certification Decision
sec.p: While our results in the previous section have established that obtaining certification from CGC has a big impact on the price received, this is also a fairly expensive strategy. CGC’s fees range from $20 to $95 per book depending on the turnaround time and estimated value. The customer also pays the shipping costs (both ways) and any insurance. Our first step is to estimate the costs of certification and compare them with the estimated benefits.19Using the equation (2) estimates intable 3, we first estimate the value of the comic without certification and then with certification; finally, we calculate the benefit of certification as the difference between the two.20Obviously, this procedure assumes that CGC and the seller assign the same grade to the comic—an assumption explored below.

According to our calculations, the benefits of certification exceed the costs for 56.8% of our sample of 3,664 auctioned comics. By comparison, only 27.9% are actually certified. This discrepancy implies that (1) sellers of uncertified comics tend to claim grades higher than those that would be assigned by CGC, (2) our estimated benefits of certification are too high or our estimated costs are too low, and/or (3) sellers underestimate the benefits of certification. While Jin and Kato (2002) report that sellers of self‐graded baseball cards exaggerate their quality, since negative feedbacks from buyers are quite rare (about 0.5%),24it appears that few sellers are grossly inflating the grades claimed for their uncertified comics. Since CGC was not established until 1999, it is possible that some sellers were unaware of its benefits; we find evidence below consistent with this hypothesis.

Aside from overestimating the likelihood of certification, our comparison of estimated benefits with estimated costs predicts certification fairly well. When the estimated costs of certification exceed the benefits, certification is rare—about 8.0%. When estimated benefits exceed estimated costs, 43.0% are certified. Overall, the model correctly predicts an issue’s certification status 64.2% of the time.

Our next question is how the decision to seek certification depends on the seller’s reputation. According to our analysis inSection IV, certification has a larger impact on price if the seller has a nascent or nonexistent reputation or if her reputation is relatively negative. This implies that, all other things equal, sellers with negative or underdeveloped reputations should be more likely to seek certification. So the likelihood of certification should be positively related to NEGPCT and negatively related to the number of feedbacks from previous customers. For the latter we use FEEDBACKS = ln(# of positive feedbacks + # of negative feedbacks + 1). On the other hand, the costs of certification should be lower for big‐volume sellers since CGC gives a 20% discount to dealers and high‐volume sellers can lower shipping costs by bundling several comics together. This cost difference implies that sellers with high values for FEEDBACKS should be more likely to seek certification. Finally, established sellers may be more aware of the benefits of certification (particularly since there was no certification agency until 1999) than novices. If so, then again the likelihood of certification should be positively related to FEEDBACKS.

A potential cost of certification not captured by our monetary measure is the time involved. If a customer seeks the least costly level of service, certification can take a couple of months. On the presumption that time might matter more to those seeking to sell their comic in a short period, we include in the probit estimation a measure of the length of the auction, DAYS, which takes values of 3, 5, 7, or 10. The estimated equation is
whereN[ ] is the cumulative standard normal distribution.

Results are presented intable 5. As expected, the likelihood of certification is strongly related to its estimated net benefit. The coefficient of FEEDBACKS is also positive and highly significant, indicating that sellers with well‐established reputations are more likely to seek certification than sellers with nonexistent or fledgling reputations, which is consistent with both the hypothesis that the costs of certification are lower for high‐volume sellers and the hypothesis that experienced sellers are more cognizant of the benefits. While our results intable 3indicated that certification has a greater positive impact on the price if the seller has an inchoative or negative reputation, there is no evidence that such sellers are more likely to seek certification. The variables NEGPCT and DAYS are not significant. Table 5

Since its purpose is purely to correct for the truncated nature of the data, we exclude the inverse Mills ratio variable and also assume that no reserve price is set.

These are the prices in effect during our sample period. They have increased slightly since. Dealers receive a 20% discount from these rates, and there is also a $5–$10 discount to regrade comics whose casing has been opened.
Note that sellers can reduce shipping costs per issue by sending more than one comic book at a time; indeed there is a three‐book minimum to qualify for the $20 rate.
Specifically, we assume that the seller has no reputation, that a scan is provided, and that the auction lasts seven days.

This is based on figures for sellers at the time of the sale. We cannot observe feedbacks on the particular auctions in our sample but would expect them to match those for previous auctions by the same sellers.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Information Disclosure
sec.p: We have seen above that almost all (96.5%) online sellers provide scans and that failure to do so lowers the price roughly 11%–16%. Since so few sellers fail to provide a scan, one possible explanation for the few who do not is that they lack the technology or knowledge to do so and find the costs of acquiring this technology too high. Since the costs of this technology are relatively fixed, infrequent sellers should be less likely to acquire it, implying that the likelihood that a scanned image is provided should be positively correlated with the number of past sales as proxied by FEEDBACKS. Likewise, the dollar benefits of scanning should be higher for higher‐value comics. To test whether scans are more common on higher‐value comics, we relate the scan likelihood to an estimate of the comic’s value, VALUEINDEX, on the basis of the BOOK and GRADE variables and the parameter values from equation (2) intable 3. If failure to provide a scan does indeed signal a lower‐quality seller, then the scan likelihood should be inversely correlated with NEGPCT. Finally, if the comic is certified by CGC, a scan should provide little additional information as to the comic’s condition, in which case sellers may not provide a scan because they view it as superfluous, implying a negative coefficient for the CERT dummy. However, a scan still provides confirmation that the issue is that claimed by the seller, for example, the firstSpidermanissue instead of the fifth, and that the comic is indeed certified.
To test these hypotheses, we estimate the probit equation

Results are presented intable 6. Scans are much less likely if the comic is offered by a first‐time or infrequent seller, suggesting that the main reason some sellers fail to provide scans is that they lack the knowledge and/or technology to do so. This may explain why the market reaction to failure to provide a scan is relatively modest (11%–16%) in that buyers may recognize that it signals more about the seller’s technological sophistication than it does about her honesty or the condition of the book. However, the significant negative coefficient for NEGPCT implies that unreliable sellers are somewhat less likely to provide a scan. There is no evidence that scans are less likely on certified comics and only very weak evidence that scans are more likely for higher‐value comics. Table 6

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Warranties
sec.p: InSection IV, we found no evidence that offering a warranty in the form of a money‐back guarantee affects the price in any significant way. Nonetheless, such warranties are offered in conjunction with 14.2% of our observed auctions, raising the question of what advantage those offering warranties think they bestow. Our first question is whether warranties help distinguish between low‐ and high‐quality sellers. The signaling rationale for warranties is that the expected cost to high‐quality sellers is small since the expected number of returns is low but prohibitive to low‐quality sellers since the expected number of returns is much larger. If indeed warranties tend to be offered by higher‐quality sellers, then we would expect them to be offered by those with few negative feedbacks from previous customers, that is, low values of NEGPCT. On the other hand, warranties could be viewed as a substitute for reputation by those with inchoate or negative reputations. Despite the lack of any evidence of such an effect from our price estimations, some sellers with an undeveloped or negative reputation may feel that offering a warranty will compensate for the lack of a strong, positive reputation. If this reputation substitution hypothesis is correct, then the presence of warranties should be negatively correlated with FEEDBACKS and positively correlated with NEGPCT. Along the same lines, sellers may view warranties as a substitute for third‐party certification. Finally, we once again include the variable VALUEINDEX on the theory that if the costs to the buyer of enforcing such warranties are substantial but fixed, then enforcement makes sense for high‐price but not low‐price books. If warranties are a sham offered by low‐quality sellers in an attempt to mislead customers, then they will tend to be offered on lower‐value books, where the cost of enforcement relative to the payoff is small. To test these hypotheses, we estimate the equation

The evidence intable 6indicates that most warranties are not shams. They tend to be offered by higher‐quality sellers—FEEDBACKS has a significant positive coefficient whereas NEGPCT’s is negative and significant—who probably intend to honor them. Also the positive coefficient for VALUEINDEX indicates that warranties tend to be offered on higher‐value comics, where the benefits to the buyer of enforcing the warranty should be higher. This evidence is somewhat inconsistent with that in tables2and3in that the evidence intable 6indicates that warranties are more likely to be issued by higher‐quality sellers, whereas the evidence in tables2and3indicates that the presence of a warranty has little impact on the price. Apparently buyers view reputation and certification as better indicators of a comic’s likely quality and feel that they subsume the information in the WARRANTY variable.25

While the coefficients of FEEDBACKS and NEGPCT are inconsistent with the hypothesis that sellers with negative or undeveloped reputations use warranties as a substitute for reputation, the significant negative coefficient of the CERT variable indicates that some sellers do view warranties as a possible substitute for certification. Expressed another way, sellers of certified comics apparently see little need to offer a warranty.

fn.p: Along these lines, if we reestimate the eq. (2) relation without the two reputation variables, the coefficient of the warranty dummy increases. However, it is still not quite significant at the .05 level.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: The Certification Signal and Bidder Rationality
sec.p: Finally, we explore whether bidders consider the costs and benefits of certification in evaluating the certification signal. If, on the basis of claimed characteristics of the comic, the apparent benefits of certification exceed the apparent costs, as they do for 56.8% of our sample, then rational bidders should question why a seller failed to seek certification if the condition of the issue was truly as high as claimed. They may well conclude that the reason was that she feared CGC would assign a lower grade. If the apparent net benefit of certification to the seller is negative (43.2% of our sample), there is no such reason to question the claimed grade of uncertified comics. In other words, failure to obtain certification should lower the expected condition of the comic only if the apparent benefit of certification exceeds the apparent cost. On the other hand, certification should reduce uncertainty about the comic’s condition in either case. To the extent that this uncertainty reduction is valued by bidders, obtaining certification should raise the price regardless of the apparent costs and benefits.

Since we found intable 3that certification has much more impact on the price of high‐graded than on the price of low‐graded comics, our evidence to this point is consistent with the hypothesis that bidders penalize failure to seek certification more if the apparent benefits exceed the costs. As a more direct test of this hypothesis, we add a dummy variable, FAILURE i , which is equal to one if issueiis uncertifiedandthe estimated benefits of certification exceed the costs and zero otherwise to the specification in equation (2). When equation (2) is reestimated with this variable, the coefficient of \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{FAILURE}\,_{i}=-.0567$ \end{document} with at‐statistic of −2.63, indicating that bidders do penalize failure to obtain certification more when it appears profitable.26

Finally, we ask whether certification sends a positive signal when the apparent costs exceed the benefits. In this case, there is not the reason to doubt the claimed grade of uncertified comics that there is when the net benefits are positive, but certification still reduces uncertainty regarding the claimed grade that may be valued. To test whether certification still matters, we estimateequation (1)over the subsample for which the estimated net benefits of certification are negative. If certification is not valued by bidders in this case, the coefficient of the certification dummy, CERT i , should be zero. In fact the estimated coefficient is .369, indicating that certification has a substantial impact on the price received even when there is no reason to doubt the claimed grade of uncertified comics.

fn.p: Since the other coefficients are virtually unchanged from those shown intable 3, we do not report them here. They are available on request.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Reputation
sec.p: We now summarize the implications of our findings for each of the four signaling strategies, starting with reputation. We find that both what prospective buyers know about a seller and how much they know matter. Sellers with good reputations, as measured by the proportion of negative feedbacks, receive higher prices than sellers with poor reputations. When the proportion of negative feedbacks is held constant, sellers with many feedbacks (both good and bad) from previous customers receive higher prices than sellers with few feedback ratings from previous customers. In a Bayesian framework, our results indicate that buyers attach a high probability of fraud or poor service to sellers with no prior feedbacks but that this prior is very weakly held and adjusted rapidly as evidence becomes available.

While reputations affect the price, they are less important than third‐party certification in explaining price differences. Our results indicate that for all except the least expensive comics, a novice seller offering a certified comic for sale receives a higher price than a seller with a well‐established, highly positive reputation offering an uncertified comic at the same grade. In the absence of a certification process, reputation might matter more. However, given the availability of a certification process, buyers apparently question why sellers do not seek certification of supposedly high‐quality, high‐value comics, even if the seller’s reputation is spotless. As expected, we find that reputation has a greater impact on price when the issue is not certified. In this sense, certification and reputation appear to be substitutes. However, we find no evidence that sellers treat them as substitutes since sellers with well‐established reputations are more, not less, likely to seek certification.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Certification
sec.p: According to our estimates, the strongest signal that a seller of high‐quality classic comics can send is to seek certification by a respected third party. We find that certification raises the price received by over 50% on average and that the percentage varies from 0% for the lowest grade to over 100% at the highest grades. In a sense, this should not be surprising. In financial markets, virtually all new security issues are accomplished by certifications from several third parties including auditors, underwriters, and possibly bond‐rating agencies such as Moody's and Standard and Poors. In product markets, products are often submitted to testing laboratories, and well‐respected names sell branding rights to less well‐known companies. Certification seems to warrant more attention by economic researchers than it has received to date.

Our research suggests that there are two reasons for certification’s substantial impact on the price. First, bidders discount the claimed grade of uncertified comics when logically it appears that the seller should have sought certification if the claimed grade was correct. Second, bidders appear to value the risk reduction that certification affords. In other words certification raises the mean and lowers the variance of the bidders’ evaluations of the comic’s likely condition, and both effects appear to be rewarded by the market.

One question that this large premium raises is why more sellers do not seek certification. Certainly part of the reason is that it is fairly costly, yet we estimate that the benefits of certification exceed the costs for 56.8% of the comics whereas the actual percentage certified is 27.9%. One possible explanation is that sellers claim inflated grades for uncertified comics that they fear the certifying agency would lower, and we find some evidence for this. However, substantial grade misrepresentation is hard to reconcile with the fact that negative feedbacks from buyers are quite rare. Another possible explanation is that since certification is a relatively new phenomenon in this market (having been introduced in 1999), sellers are still learning the benefits. Consistent with this explanation, we find that frequent sellers are considerably more likely to seek certification, even though benefits to certification are considerably greater to those sellers with an inchoate or nonexistent reputation.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Warranties
sec.p: In 14.2% of our auctions, the seller offered a warranty in the form of a money‐back guarantee, yet our evidence shows that these warranties had little impact on the price. We see two possible reasons why buyers apparently ignored the presence of warranties. First, buyers may feel that the costs of enforcing the warranties are too high to make them effective. Second, buyers may reason that there are stronger signaling strategies, certification especially, available to high‐quality sellers and so discount the warranty signal. Despite the fact that warranties apparently do not affect the price, a minority of sellers clearly do view warranties as a strategy worth pursuing. We find no evidence that sellers view warranties as a substitute for reputation but do find evidence that they are viewed as a substitute for certification.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Information Disclosure
sec.p: Some form of information disclosure precedes virtually every security, good, or service trade. Examples include financial statements, specifications, and advertising. In the online comic book market the major information disclosure is a scan of the comic. Scans are provided in 96.5% of the observed auctions. We find that with reputation and other factors unchanged, failure to provide a scan lowers the price roughly 11%–16%. While significant, this impact is less than we had expected. Since we find that sellers who fail to provide scans are normally those with nonexistent or embryonic reputations, their comics would tend to sell for lower prices anyway, and buyers may reason that the lack of a scan probably reflects a lack of sophistication and resources rather than low quality. In any case, buyers apparently feel that the signal that failure to provide a scan sends has only modest informational value.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: General Observations
sec.p: Overall, our results emphasize how important information asymmetries between sellers (or issuers) and buyers are and how much sellers are willing to expend to signal the quality of their products. As evidenced by high feedback ratings, the vast majority of sellers of classic comic books clearly feel that the long‐run benefits of developing a reputation for honesty and high quality outweigh the considerable short‐run benefits of overestimating the comic’s true quality. While the cost of certification is substantial, many sellers are willing pay it.

Our results indicate that signals that reduce bidders’ uncertainty about the quality of the item being sold are valued by the market as well as those signals that change perceptions. In other words, even if the expected quality is unchanged, signals that lower the variance are valued. If two sellers have the same ratio of negative to positive feedbacks but A’s reputation is based on many more feedbacks from buyers than B's, A will tend to receive a higher price. Likewise, certification raises the price even in those cases in which the expected grade is the same.

Our results also emphasize the importance of considering alternatives when analyzing signaling strategies. We find that the seller’s reputation matters much more when the comic book being offered for sale has not been certified by a trusted third party. In the absence of certification, money‐back guarantees and reputation might matter much more; but since this highly effective signaling strategy is available, rational buyers apparently tend to question why a seller chose a less effective strategy if indeed the quality of the offered comic was as high as claimed.
